docs.lead_paragraph: One day during medical school, my classmates and I learned that one of the most well-liked doctors-in-training in the hospital had had a seizure while leading morning work rounds. The sight of him writhing had caused the other doctors and nurses on the ward to panic. Some stood mute, frozen with fear. An intern, believing that the seizure arose from low blood sugar levels, took his half-eaten jelly doughnut and held it against the mouth of his seizing colleague. Others yelled to the ward secretary to ''call a code,'' and continued to do so even after another dozen doctors and nurses had already arrived on the floor.

headline.main: An Epilepsy Specialist With a Patient's Point of View

docs.abstract: Dr Pauline W Chen Doctor and Patient column features interview with Dr Brien J Smith, neurologist and epilepsy specialist who himself suffers from the disorder; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Genentech will ask the F.D.A. to rethink its proposal to revoke the approval of Avastin for breast cancer on the grounds that new studies did not confirm that the drug helped patients.

docs.lead_paragraph: FALK--Peter. Columbia University Medical Center mourns the passing of Peter Falk, a great friend to our Taub Institute for Research on Alzheimer's Disease and the Aging Brain. His ongoing generosity was vital in helping our researchers continue their work uncovering the causes of Alzheimer's, Parkinson's and other age-related brain diseases and discovering ways to prevent and cure these diseases. All of us at Columbia extend our condolences to his wife, Shera Danese, his daughters, Jackie and Catherine, and to the rest of his family. Lee Goldman, MD Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine Executive Vice President, Columbia University Richard Mayeux, MD, MSc Gertrude H. Sergievsky Professor of Neurology, Psychiatry & Epidemiology Chairman, Department of Neurology Co-Director, Taub Institute Michael L. Shelanski, MD, PhD Delafield Professor and Chairman Department of Pathology and Cell Biology Co-Director, Taub Institute

docs.lead_paragraph: IT is an American impulse to covet the new and improved -- whether it's a faster computer, a smarter cellphone or a more fuel-efficient car. And in medicine, too, new drugs, devices and procedures have advanced patient care. But the promise of innovation can also prove a trap, a situation now playing out with dire consequences for possibly tens of thousands of people who received artificial hips intended to let them remain active.

headline.main: In Medicine, New Isn't Always Improved

docs.abstract: Tens of thousands of people who received new metal artificial hips could run into problems, as the implants can shed dangerous metallic debris through wear; hips are among a host of supposed innovations that have imploded not long after introduction; experts say doctors should use better yardsticks in embracing new technologies when existing treatments are highly effective; drawing; photo (L)
